On Thu, Jan 09, 2003 at 03:17:38PM -0800, S. Mike Dierken wrote:
> Why is introspecting the message body not 'visibility'?

It's part of it, sure; the syntax part. 8-)

> An explosion of application meaning (lots of custom methods/operations) will
> negate the benefit of visibility (being able to find the method/operation in
> a message) - administration will become difficult.

Right.

> > Please respond with any examples, or brief explanations, that you feel
> > might help out.  Thanks!  I sense an opportunity here.  A couple of WG
> > members are really close to getting it.
> What is the 'it' that they should be getting? That visibility is good? Or
> that visibility without a constrained interface gets you nowhere?

The "it" is what visibility is, and why it's good, though I think if
the former is recognized, the latter will be clear.

FWIW, and to answer Seairth, here's a quote from Roy's dissertation;

"[...]What makes HTTP significantly different from RPC is that the requests are directed to resources using a generic interface with standard semantics that can be interpreted by intermediaries almost as well as by the machines that originate services.[...]"
 -- http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_5_2

MB
